titleStmt.title: Fitter to see Him, I may be

publicationStmt.p: The Poems of Emily Dickinson, Johnson, 1955

lg.l: Fitter to see Him, I may be
For the long Hindrance -- Grace -- to Me --
With Summers, and with Winters, grow,
Some passing Year -- A charmcharm trait bestow
To make Me fairest of the Earth --
The Waiting -- then -- will seem so worth
I shall impute with half a pain
The blame that I was commoncommon chosen -- then --
Time'sTime's Time to anticipate His Gaze --
thethe It's first -- Delight -- and then -- Surprise --
The turning o'er and o'er my face
For Evidence it be the Grace --
He left behind One Day -- So less
He seek Conviction, That -- be This --
I Only must not grow so new
That He --He -- He'll mistake -- and ask for me
Of me -- when first unto the Door
I go -- to Elsewhere go no more --
I only must not change so fair
He'll sigh -- "The Real OneReal One Other -- She -- is Where?"
The Love, tho, will instructinstruct array me right
I shall be perfect -- in His sight --
If He perceive the other Truth --
Upon an Excellenter Youth --
How sweet I shall not lack in Vain --
But gain -- thro' loss -- Through painpain Grief -- obtain --
The Beauty that reward Him bestbest most --
The Beauty of Belief --Belief -- Demand -- at Rest --
